A BJT (Bipolar Junction Transistor) is another three-terminal device that can be used to build an amplifier. The circuit shown is a model of an amplifier stage using a BJT in its region of linear operation. The crude model of the BJT in this circuit is just an independent voltage source and a current-controlled current source.
A 2N3904 has \(100 < \beta < 300\), so let's choose \(\beta = $beta\) and \(V_{BE} = 0.6\)V. Let the power supply voltage be \(V_S = $VS\)V and the resistors be \(R_{B1} = $RB1\Omega\), \(R_{B2} = $RB2\Omega\), \(R_E = $RE\Omega\), and \(R_C = $RC\Omega\).
Now compute the operating point. Hint: Because the current \(i_B\) controls the current source you will need to make a node equation for each of the two nodes on either side of the independent source \(V_{BE}\), even though the potential on one of those nodes gives the potential on the other.
What is the operating-point voltage \(V_{IN}\), in Volts?
What is the operating-point voltage \(V_E\), in Volts?
What is the operating-point current \(I_E\), in Amperes?
What is the operating-point voltage \(V_{OUT}\), in Volts?
Now that we know the operating-point conditions.
Note: You do not need to have determined the operating point in this circuit do the next parts of this problem. They do not depend on the operating point because this model is entirely constructed from linear elements and independent sources.
So, let's now determine the incremental behavior.
Hint: Draw the small-signal circuit model for this circuit.
Assume that the input increases in voltage by \(v_{in} = $vin\)V. What is the resulting \(v_e\), in volts?
This causes \(i_E\) to change. What is \(i_e\), in Amperes?
This causes \(i_C\) to change. What is \(i_c\), in Amperes?
This causes \(v_{OUT}\) to change. What is \(v_{out}\), in Volts?
So, what is the incremental gain \(\frac{v_{out}}{v_{in}}\)?
